options.label: B

options.text: To increase food production and storage

title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in studying living brains?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too small to be observed.

options.label: B
options.text: They are shielded by a thick skull and protective tissue, and composed of billions of interconnected cells.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too fragile to be handled.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too simple to understand.

multiple-choice.question: Which technique measures electrical activity in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI)

options.label: B
options.text: Positron emission tomography (PET)

options.label: C
options.text: Electroencephalography (EEG)

options.label: D
options.text: Computed Tomography (CT)

multiple-choice.question: What type of activity does EEG measure in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen consumption by brain cells

options.label: B
options.text: Electrical activity in the form of waves

options.label: C
options.text: Radioactive elements introduced into the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Blood flow in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is a key advantage of fMRI over EEG?

options.label: A
options.text: It is non-invasive and relatively inexpensive.

options.label: B
options.text: It can pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters.

options.label: C
options.text: It is faster than EEG.

options.label: D
options.text: It measures both electrical and magnetic activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is a key disadvantage of PET compared to EEG and fMRI?

options.label: A
options.text: It is non-invasive but relatively expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: It is less accurate than EEG and fMRI.

options.label: C
options.text: It takes minutes for the tracer to circulate and changes to show up.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more invasive than EEG and fMRI.

multiple-choice.question: What is a primary purpose of using multiple techniques to study the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine exactly where any particular pattern originates.

options.label: B
options.text: To connect what happens in the brain with our behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the complex chemistry in the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the relationship between memory and specific brain regions.

multiple-choice.question: What is a primary limitation of current brain imaging techniques?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive to use.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too complex to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: They are limited by how much we still don't know about the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: They lack the precision to measure individual neurons.

multiple-choice.question: How can using more electrodes or sophisticated data-processing algorithms improve EEG results?

options.label: A
options.text: It can increase the spatial resolution to within a few millimeters.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help determine where any particular pattern originates.

options.label: C
options.text: It can increase the speed of EEG measurements.

options.label: D
options.text: It can simplify the interpretation of EEG signals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using a tracer in PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure electrical activity in the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure oxygen consumption by brain cells.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the complex chemistry in the brain by binding to specific molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: To enhance the brain's activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future direction of brain imaging research?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop more advanced imaging and analysis technology to provide more accurate results.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the relationship between memory and specific parts of the brain using only EEG.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the complex chemistry in the brain using only PET.

options.label: D
options.text: To connect what happens in the brain with our behavior using only fMRI.
